etymology.description: 艹(艸) (cǎo, "grass") + 盧(盧) (lú, "black") = grass or plant related -> reed
etymology.interpretation: The character combines the semantic 艹(艸) (cǎo, "grass") indicating it is a type of plant and the phonetic 盧(盧) (lú, "black") to suggest its pronunciation. This makes it intuitive as a representation of 'reed.'
etymology.simplification: 蘆(蘆)→芦(蘆): 盧(盧) (lú, "black") is replaced with a simplified form to reduce complexity.

examples.chinese: 湖边生长着茂盛的芦(蘆)。
examples.pinyin: Hú biān shēngzhǎng zhe màoshèng de lú.
examples.english: Reeds grow luxuriantly by the lake.

examples.chinese: 河岸上芦(蘆)随风摇曳(隨風搖曳)，发出沙沙声(發出沙沙聲)。
examples.pinyin: Hé àn shàng lú suí fēng yáoyè, fāchū shā shā shēng.
examples.english: The reeds on the riverbank sway in the wind, producing a rustling sound.
